title: 105_hr2655
content: The "Clean Books Act" aims to eliminate 69 unfunded education programs to streamline bookkeeping for the Department of Education. Congress found that over 100 education programs are unfunded, with no funding requested by the President or provided by the 103rd or 104th Congress. The "Clean Books Act" repeals various provisions under the Adult Education Act and the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Applied Technology Education Act, including workplace literacy partnerships, English literacy grants, education programs for commercial drivers, adult literacy volunteer training, and state-administered programs for vocational education support. State assistance for vocational education support programs by community-based organizations, consumer and homemaking education, comprehensive career guidance and counseling programs, business-labor-education partnership for training, and supplementary state grants for facilities and equipment are all covered under different parts of the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Applied Technology Education Act. Supplementary state grants for facilities and equipment, community education employment centers, vocational education lighthouse schools, demonstration programs, and certain bilingual programs are all covered under different parts of the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Applied Technology Education Act. Additionally, the Community School Partnerships Act is included in the Improving Community Schools Act. The Partnership Act, Educational Research Act, and provisions of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 are repealed, including innovative school projects, dropout assistance, Impact Aid Program, and special programs. Special programs and projects to improve educational opportunities for Indian children, adult education programs for Indians, federal administration, authorization of appropriations, and the Delugo Territorial Education Improvement Program are outlined in various subparts and sections of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Family and Community Endeavor Schools Act and Goals 2000: Educate America Act are repealed. Provisions under the Higher Education Act of 1965 related to state and local programs for teacher excellence and national teacher academies are also repealed. The Higher Education Act of 1965 includes various programs such as class size demonstration grants, middle school teaching demonstration programs, small state teaching initiative, early childhood education training, and grants for workplace and community transition training for incarcerated youth offenders. Repeals of various provisions from different acts including the Higher Education Amendments of 1992, National Literacy Act of 1991, and Rehabilitation Act of 1973. This includes repealing career advancement training consortia, vocational rehabilitation services for individuals with disabilities, loan guarantees for community rehabilitation programs, comprehensive rehabilitation centers, and special demonstration programs. The curr_chunk discusses various services and programs for individuals with disabilities under the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, including reader services for the blind, interpreter services for the deaf, community service employment pilot programs, business opportunities, transportation service grants, and projects for high-quality placements. The curr_chunk discusses specific subsections of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, including early intervention and transition demonstration projects, barriers to rehabilitation outcomes for minorities, studies on management and service delivery, and a national commission on rehabilitation services. The curr_chunk provides details on specific subsections of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 related to model personal assistance services systems, demonstration projects for worker skills, model systems for severe disabilities, distance learning, training for impartial hearing officers, and recruitment of urban personnel. The curr_chunk repeals specific sections of the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act and the Technology-Related Assistance for Individuals With Disabilities Act of 1988.
